content:
It's a great question, and one that is difficult to answer with certainty since there are many factors that go into creating parity among teams in the MLB. However, the pandemic could potentially lead to more parity in the league if the reduced spending among big market teams allows smaller market teams to compete more effectively.

With big market teams being more cautious in their spending due to the financial impact of the pandemic, it's possible that smaller market teams will be able to sign more talented players to their rosters, narrowing the talent gap between the top and bottom of the league. Additionally, smaller market teams may be better positioned to weather the financial impacts of the pandemic, as they often operate on smaller budgets and have less reliance on game-day revenue.

However, it's important to note that big market teams will still have significant advantages in terms of revenue sources and larger fan bases, which can contribute to a strong financial foundation and help build a competitive roster. Additionally, there are many other factors that go into building a successful team, including scouting, drafting, and player development, so it's possible that smaller market teams will still struggle to keep up with the larger, more established teams in the league.

Overall, while the pandemic could potentially lead to more parity among teams in the MLB, it remains to be seen exactly how the financial impacts of the pandemic will play out in terms of team competitiveness and building strong, sustainable rosters.
